title: How to Make a Bouillabaisse

steps.headline: Prepare all your ingredients and utensils.
steps.description: Make sure the fish you use is at room temperature, and has been for at least 20 minutes, so they don't slow down the speed at which the stew boils. Laying out all of your ingredients and utensils before you start making the bouillabaisse allows for better organization and more efficient preparation.

steps.headline: Pour the olive oil into one of the cooking pots and heat it over medium heat.
Add the chopped onion and leek until they're soft and slightly translucent.
Stir in the garlic.
steps.description: Let it cook for approximately 1 minute until it releases its fragrance.

steps.headline: Add the salt, saffron, fresh herbs, tomatoes, water, as well as the fish heads, bones, trimmings and shrimp shells.
Bring the mixture to a simmer.
Reduce the heat slightly until the stew slowly bubbles, but does not boil.
Allow the stew to cook for 30 minutes.
Strain the stew over the second cooking pot.
Take the solids out of the strainer and discard them.
Put the second pot, now holding the strained stew, on the stove and bring the stew to a boil so the olive oil thoroughly mixes into the rest of the stew instead of floating on top.
Add the shrimp and let them cook for 1-to-2 minutes until they turn pink.
Add the wild cod, halibut and sole as well as the mussels or clams.
Cover the stew and let it simmer.
steps.description: Check it every few minutes to see if the mussels or clams have opened.

steps.headline: Taste the stew.
steps.description: If necessary, add extra salt or pepper, or whatever herb is your personal preference.

steps.headline: Serve the bouillabaisse with fresh bread or toasted garlic bread.
steps.description: The traditional way of serving a bouillabaisse is to strain out the fish from the stew, then serve the stew as a first course with toasted garlic bread with sauce rouille. The fish platter is then served as the second course, usually with thinly sliced potatoes with butter.
